name: carbon
content:
carbon

noun
 
 
/ˈkɑːbən/
 
/ˈkɑːrbən/
jump to other results
  1.  
    [uncountable]
    (symbol C)
    a chemical element. Carbon is found in all living things, existing in a pure state as diamond and graphite.
    • carbon fibre
    • iron with a high carbon content
    Topics Physics and chemistryb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • pure
    • organic
    • radioactive
    • …
    carbon + noun
    • content
    • atom
    • isotope
    • …
    phrases
    • a form of carbon
    See full entry
  2.  
    [uncountable] used when referring to the gas carbon dioxide in terms of the effect it has on the earth’s climate in causing global warming
    • carbon emissions/levels/taxes
    • (British English) How do we move to a low-carbon economy?
    see also low-carbon, zero-carbonTopics The environmentb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • pure
    • organic
    • radioactive
    • …
    carbon + noun
    • content
    • atom
    • isotope
    • …
    phrases
    • a form of carbon
    See full entry
  3. [countable]
    (also carbon copy)
    a copy of a document, letter, etc. made with carbon paper
  4. [countable]
    (also carbon copy)
    a person or thing that is very similar to somebody/something else
  5. [countable] a piece of carbon paper
    6. Word Originlate 18th cent.: from French carbone, from Latin carbo, carbon- ‘coal, charcoal’.
See carbon in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee carbon in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: carbon

name: carbon copy
content:
carbon copy

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˈkɒpi/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˈkɑːpi/
(also carbon)
jump to other results
  1. a copy of a document, letter, etc. made with carbon paper see also cc
  2. a person or thing that is very similar to somebody/something else
    • She is a carbon copy of her sister.
    • The twins were carbon copies of each other.
See carbon copy in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: carbon copy

name: carbon copy
content:
carbon copy

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˈkɒpi/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˈkɑːpi/
(also carbon)
jump to other results
  1. a copy of a document, letter, etc. made with carbon paper see also cc
  2. a person or thing that is very similar to somebody/something else
    • She is a carbon copy of her sister.
    • The twins were carbon copies of each other.
See carbon copy in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: carbon copy

name: carbon debt
content:
carbon debt

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˈdet/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˈdet/
jump to other results
  1. the difference between the effects of the carbon footprint of a country, group, person, etc. and anything that has been agreed or done to reduce these effects
    • A massive carbon debt will be created when the forests are harvested.
    • With the continued use of fossil fuels, the country’s carbon debt increases each year.
    Topics The environmentc2
Check pronunciation: carbon debt

name: low-carbon
content:
low-carbon

adjective
 
/ˌləʊ ˈkɑːbən/
 
/ˌləʊ ˈkɑːrbən/
 [usually before noun]
jump to other results
  1. causing only a relatively small amount of carbon dioxide to be released into the atmosphere
    • the transition to a low-carbon economy
    • These technologies will play an essential part in the new low-carbon energy system.
    Topics The environmentc1
Check pronunciation: low-carbon

name: zero-carbon
content:
zero-carbon

adjective
 
/ˌzɪərəʊ ˈkɑːbən/
 
/ˌzɪrəʊ ˈkɑːrbən/
jump to other results
  1. in which the amount of carbon dioxide produced has been reduced to nothing or is balanced by actions that protect the environment synonym carbon-neutral
    • a zero-carbon house that uses no energy from external sources
    Topics The environmentc1
See zero-carbon in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: zero-carbon

name: carbon credit
content:
carbon credit

noun
 
/ˈkɑːbən kredɪt/
 
/ˈkɑːrbən kredɪt/
jump to other results
  1. a key element in the system of national and international carbon trading. A country or organization has the right to produce a particular amount of carbon dioxide and other gases that cause global warming, which is expressed in terms of carbon credits, which may be traded between countries or organizations.
    • The sale of carbon credits can finance renewable energy projects.
    Topics The environmentc2
  2. a carbon offset, which a person or company may choose to buy as a way of reducing the level of carbon dioxide for which they are responsible
    • Wind energy companies sell carbon credits to consumers.
    Topics The environmentc2
See carbon credit in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: carbon credit

name: carbon cycle
content:
carbon cycle

noun
 
/ˈkɑːbən saɪkl/
 
/ˈkɑːrbən saɪkl/
[usually singular]
jump to other results
  1. the processes by which carbon is changed from one form to another within the environment, for example in plants and when wood or oil is burned
See carbon cycle in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee carbon cycle in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: carbon cycle

name: carbon dating
content:
carbon dating

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˈdeɪtɪŋ/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˈdeɪtɪŋ/
(also formal radiocarbon dating)
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. a method of calculating the age of very old objects by measuring the amounts of different forms of carbon in themTopics Scientific researchc1, Historyc1
See carbon dating in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: carbon dating

name: carbon offset
content:
carbon offset

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˈɒfset/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˈɔːfset/
 [countable, uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. a way for a company or person to reduce the level of carbon dioxide for which they are responsible by paying money to a company that works to reduce the total amount produced in the world, for example by planting trees
    • carbon offset initiatives for air travellers
    • carbon offset projects
    • Wind energy companies sell carbon offsets.
    • The country can trade carbon offset to rich polluters.
    compare carbon creditTopics The environmentc2
See carbon offset in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: carbon offset

name: carbon paper
content:
carbon paper

noun
 
/ˈkɑːbən peɪpə(r)/
 
/ˈkɑːrbən peɪpər/
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. thin paper with a dark substance on one side, that is used between two sheets of paper for making copies of written or typed documents
See carbon paper in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: carbon paper

name: carbon dioxide
content:
carbon dioxide

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən daɪˈɒksaɪd/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən daɪˈɑːksaɪd/
 [uncountable]
(symbol CO2)
jump to other results
  1. a gas breathed out by people and animals from the lungs or produced by burning carbon
    • Coke burns with oxygen to give carbon dioxide.
    • Trees absorb carbon dioxide and produce oxygen.
    Topics Physics and chemistryb2, The environmentb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverb + carbon dioxide
    • absorb
    • take in
    • emit
    • …
    carbon dioxide + noun
    • emissions
    • concentration
    • levels
    • …
    phrases
    • a build-up of carbon dioxide
    • emissions of carbon dioxide
    See full entry
See carbon dioxide in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee carbon dioxide in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: carbon dioxide

name: carbon footprint
content:
carbon footprint

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˈfʊtprɪnt/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˈfʊtprɪnt/
jump to other results
  1. a measure of the amount of carbon dioxide that is produced by the activities of a person or company
    • Flying is the biggest contribution to my carbon footprint.
    • an analysis of the carbon footprints of leading companies
    • Companies are measuring their carbon footprints.
    • a carbon footprint calculator
    Collocations The environmentThe environmentEnvironmental damage
    • cause/​contribute to climate change/​global warming
    • produce pollution/​CO2/greenhouse (gas) emissions
    • damage/​destroy the environment/​a marine ecosystem/​the ozone layer/​coral reefs
    • degrade ecosystems/​habitats/​the environment
    • harm the environment/​wildlife/​marine life
    • threaten natural habitats/​coastal ecosystems/​a species with extinction
    • deplete natural resources/​the ozone layer
    • pollute rivers and lakes/​waterways/​the air/​the atmosphere/​the environment/​oceans
    • contaminate groundwater/​the soil/​food/​crops
    • log forests/​rainforests/​trees
    Protecting the environment
    • address/​combat/​tackle the threat/​effects/​impact of climate change
    • fight/​take action on/​reduce/​stop global warming
    • limit/​curb/​control air/​water/​atmospheric/​environmental pollution
    • cut/​reduce pollution/​greenhouse gas emissions
    • offset carbon/​CO2 emissions
    • reduce (the size of) your carbon footprint
    • achieve/​promote sustainable development
    • preserve/​conserve biodiversity/​natural resources
    • protect endangered species/​a coastal ecosystem
    • prevent/​stop soil erosion/​overfishing/​massive deforestation/​damage to ecosystems
    • raise awareness of environmental issues
    • save the planet/​the rainforests/​an endangered species
    Energy and resources
    • conserve/​save/​consume/​waste energy
    • manage/​exploit/​be rich in natural resources
    • dump/​dispose of hazardous/​toxic/​nuclear waste
    • dispose of/​throw away litter/(especially British English) rubbish/(especially North American English) garbage/(North American English) trash/​sewage
    • use/​be made from recycled/​recyclable/​biodegradable material
    • recycle bottles/​packaging/​paper/​plastic/​waste
    • promote/​encourage recycling/​sustainable development/​the use of renewable energy
    • develop/​invest in/​promote renewable energy
    • reduce your dependence/​reliance on fossil fuels
    • get/​obtain/​generate/​produce electricity from wind, solar and wave power/​renewable sources
    • build/​develop a (50-megawatt/​offshore) wind farm
    • install/​be fitted with/​be powered by solar panels
    Topics The environmentb2
See carbon footprint in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: carbon footprint

name: carbon monoxide
content:
carbon monoxide

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən məˈnɒksaɪd/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən məˈnɑːksaɪd/
 [uncountable]
(symbol CO)
jump to other results
  1. a poisonous gas formed when carbon burns partly but not completely. It is produced when petrol is burned in car engines.Topics The environmentc1, Physics and chemistryc1
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryCarbon monoxide is used before these nouns:
    • fumes
    • poisoning
    See full entry
See carbon monoxide in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee carbon monoxide in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: carbon monoxide

name: carbon-neutral
content:
carbon-neutral

adjective
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˈnjuːtrəl/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˈnuːtrəl/
jump to other results
  1. in which the amount of carbon dioxide produced has been reduced to nothing or is balanced by actions that protect the environment synonym zero-carbon
    • All of these fuels are renewable and carbon-neutral.
    • a carbon-neutral house that uses no energy from external sources
    • buildings designed to be carbon-neutral
    Topics The environmentc1
See carbon-neutral in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: carbon-neutral

name: carbon trading
content:
carbon trading

noun
 
/ˈkɑːbən treɪdɪŋ/
 
/ˈkɑːrbən treɪdɪŋ/
(also emissions trading
 
/ɪˈmɪʃnz treɪdɪŋ/
 
/ɪˈmɪʃnz treɪdɪŋ/
)
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. a system that gives countries and organizations the right to produce a particular amount of carbon dioxide and other gases that cause global warming, and allows them to sell this right
    • a global carbon trading system
    • Carbon trading has not been very effective so far in addressing global warming.
    Topics The environmentc1
See carbon trading in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: carbon trading

name: carbon sequestration
content:
carbon sequestration

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˌsiːkwəˈstreɪʃn/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˌsiːkwəˈstreɪʃn/
 [uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. the process of storing carbon dioxide that has been collected and removed from the atmosphere, in solid or liquid form see also carbon capture and storageTopics The environmentc2
Check pronunciation: carbon sequestration

name: carbon capture and storage
content:
carbon capture and storage

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˌkæptʃər ən ˈstɔːrɪdʒ/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˌkæptʃər ən ˈstɔːrɪdʒ/
(also carbon capture and sequestration
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˌkæptʃər ən ˌsiːkwəˈstreɪʃn/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˌkæptʃər ən ˌsiːkwəˈstreɪʃn/
)
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. the process of collecting carbon dioxide produced by burning coal, oil, etc. and other industrial processes, and storing it so that it does not affect the atmosphere see also carbon sequestrationTopics The environmentc1
Check pronunciation: carbon capture and storage
